description: From Middle English quaylen, from Middle Dutch queilen, quēlen, from Old Dutch *quelan, from Proto-West Germanic *kwelan, from Proto-Germanic *kwelaną (“to suffer”). Doublet of queal.

verbs.description: quail (third-person singular simple present quails, present participle quailing, simple past and past participle quailed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To waste away; to fade, to wither. [from 15th c.]
(transitive, now rare) To daunt or frighten (someone). [from 16th c.]
examples: To tell the truth the prospect rather quailed him – wandering about in the gloomy corridors of a nunnery.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To lose heart or courage; to be daunted or fearful. [from 16th c.]
(intransitive) Of courage, faith, etc.: to slacken, to give way. [from 16th c.]

description: From Middle English quayle, quaile, quaille, from Anglo-Norman quaille, from Late Latin quaccola (“quail”).

entries.meaning: Any of various small game birds of the genera Coturnix, Anurophasis or Perdicula in the Old World family Phasianidae or of the New World family Odontophoridae.
examples: Quail require little water, so there is no point to putting in a guzzler if there is any permanent water within travel range.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The meat from this bird eaten as food.
(obsolete) A prostitute, so called because the quail was thought to be a very amorous bird.

description: From Middle English quaylen, qwaylen, from Old French quaillier, coaillier, from Latin coāgulāre. Doublet of coagulate.

verbs.description: quail (third-person singular simple present quails, present participle quailing, simple past and past participle quailed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To curdle or coagulate, as milk does.
